formats_plot.py¶

Contains long strings to make writing files easier.

PS: if you’re reading this online, this looks way better in the actual file

PPS: double curly braces tell Python you mean a literal curly brace when you’re formatting a string. E.g. “{a}, {b}, {{a}}”.format(a=1, b=2) produces the string “1, 2, {a}”

ncsd_python.plot_modules.formats_plot.xmgrace_Nmax_title_format = 'N\\smax\\N = {Nmax}'¶

format of xmgrace Nmax title

ncsd_python.plot_modules.formats_plot.xmgrace_axis_label_line = '{Nmax}h\\h{{-.6}}\\v{{.3}}- \\v{{-.3}}\\xW\\f{{}}\n'¶

format of an xmgrace axis label

ncsd_python.plot_modules.formats_plot.xmgrace_data_line_format = '{j} {repetition} {parity}   {energy:.4f}\n'¶

format of xmgrace line of data

ncsd_python.plot_modules.formats_plot.xmgrace_dataset_format = '{title}\n{lines}'¶

xmgrace files are made of datasets, which are a title + data lines

ncsd_python.plot_modules.formats_plot.xmgrace_format = '\nE\\sx\\N [MeV]\nlin lin\n{num_spectra_plus_2} {num_states} {num_spectra} {num_plots}              !       num_strings num_states num_specs num_plots\n\\S{Z_plus_N}\\N{element}\n{interaction_name}\n{axis_labels}\n dotted off rotate\n{data}\n\n'¶

overall format of xmgrace file
